Easy.question: What is SwiftUI primarily used for?
Which container stacks views vertically in SwiftUI?
Which property wrapper is used for local view state in SwiftUI?
Which view provides a scrollable region in SwiftUI?

What does ZStack do in SwiftUI?
options: Overlays views on top of each other

Which modifier changes the text color in SwiftUI?
Which view is best for displaying a list of rows?
What is the starting point of a SwiftUI app?
options: A struct conforming to the App protocol

Medium.question: What does @Binding provide between two SwiftUI views?
options: A two-way connection to a value

Medium.question: Which container allows lazy loading of rows in SwiftUI?
Which modifier is used to animate changes to a view’s state?
Which property wrapper subscribes to an observable reference type created outside a view?
Which view is used for grouping controls in a settings-like layout?
What does .sheet(isPresented:) present?
options: A modal view from the bottom

Medium.question: What does .onAppear perform in SwiftUI?
options: Runs code when the view becomes visible
Runs code when the app launches
Runs code only when the app terminates

Medium.question: What is the correct way to observe environment changes like color scheme?
Which view is appropriate for building navigation-based flows?
What is the purpose of the PreviewProvider in SwiftUI?
options: To provide Xcode canvas previews for a view

Hard.question: What happens internally when a @State property changes in SwiftUI?
options: The view invalidates and recomputes its body
The entire view hierarchy is destroyed
The app restarts the main run loop

Hard.question: When should @StateObject be preferred over @ObservedObject?
options: When the view owns the lifecycle of the object
When the object is passed in from a parent view

Hard.question: What is the main advantage of using .transaction in SwiftUI?
options: To customize how state changes are animated

Hard.question: Which SwiftUI feature is most closely related to diffing the view hierarchy?
options: The identity of views determined by their structure and modifiers
The unique IDs of all subviews

Hard.question: What is a potential issue when using many nested stacks (VStack/HStack) deeply?
options: Performance and layout complexity can increase
SwiftUI will not compile the body

Hard.question: How can you prevent state from resetting when a parent view is recreated?
options: Use @StateObject in the child instead of @ObservedObject

Hard.question: Why might you use a custom ViewModifier in SwiftUI?
options: To reuse complex combinations of modifiers across views

Hard.question: What is the role of EquatableView in SwiftUI?
options: To skip view updates when input values haven't changed
To force redraw for each state change
To store views in a Set

Hard.question: How can you conditionally apply a modifier in a clean way?
options: By using a custom extension that applies a modifier based on a Boolean
By using if statements only outside the body
By using only ternary operators in all views
By wrapping all modifiers in a ZStack

Hard.question: What is a common cause of 'Modifying state during view update' warnings?
options: Changing state from inside the view’s body calculation

Easy.question: What is UIKit mainly used for?
options: Building imperative user interfaces for iOS

Which class is used to display static text?

options: Constraints and positions of UI elements

Which control captures simple text input?
Which UIKit concept is responsible for responding to touch events?

Medium.question: Which method is called after a view controller’s view is loaded into memory?

options: It manages a stack of view controllers

Which delegate method configures each cell in a UITableView?

Hard.question: What is the purpose of layoutSubviews in UIView subclasses?
options: To adjust the layout of subviews when bounds change

Hard.question: Why might you use a custom CALayer subclass?
options: To implement complex, performant custom drawing

Hard.question: What is the risk of creating a strong reference cycle with delegates in UIKit?
options: It can cause memory leaks because objects never deallocate
It speeds up UI rendering but uses more CPU
It automatically cancels all network requests

Hard.question: Which approach helps improve scrolling performance in UITableView?
options: Creating new cells every time without reuse
Triggering layoutIfNeeded on every scroll step
Using synchronous network calls in cellForRowAt

Hard.question: Why might you use constraints’ contentCompressionResistancePriority?
options: To control how views resist being shrunk

Hard.question: What is the main difference between frame and bounds of a UIView?
options: Frame is in superview’s coordinate space, bounds is in the view’s own
Frame is always (0,0), bounds is not
Bounds includes transforms, frame does not

Hard.question: Why is performing heavy work on the main thread discouraged in UIKit apps?
options: It blocks UI updates and makes the app feel unresponsive
It speeds up UI but uses more memory

Hard.question: When implementing custom transitions between view controllers, which protocol is typically adopted?
What is a common use case for UIAppearance?
options: To globally customize the appearance of UIKit controls

Hard.question: Why might you override traitCollectionDidChange in a view or view controller?
options: To respond to environment changes like Dark Mode or size class changes
To respond to network reachability changes

options: To perform custom drawing with Core Graphics

Hard.question: What is a common way to support Dark Mode in AppKit?
options: Using dynamic colors and responding to effectiveAppearance changes

Hard.question: How does the responder chain help with keyboard shortcuts in AppKit?
options: It routes actions to the first object that can handle them
It always sends events to NSApplicationDelegate first

Hard.question: Why might you use NSOutlineView instead of NSTableView?

To guarantee ordering of menu items

options: It manages the event loop for input and timers

Hard.question: Why might you use NSPanel instead of NSWindow?

Easy.question: What is a storyboard in iOS development?
options: A visual representation of app UI and flow

Easy.question: Which file extension do storyboards use?
Which tool is used to edit storyboards?
Which object in a storyboard represents a screen?
What does a segue represent in a storyboard?

options: Check 'Is Initial View Controller' in Attributes Inspector
Place it at the top of the storyboard

Which storyboard element is used to create tab-based navigation?
How are interface elements connected to code from storyboards?
Which panel in Xcode lists all views and constraints in the current scene?

Medium.question: What is a common issue when using a single Main.storyboard for large apps?
options: It becomes hard to manage and merge changes

Medium.question: What is the purpose of a storyboard ID for a view controller?
options: To instantiate it programmatically from the storyboard
To track analytics of that screen
To set its tab bar position

Medium.question: Which method is typically used to prepare data before a segue transition?
What is a benefit of using multiple storyboards instead of one?
options: Improved modularity and easier team collaboration

Medium.question: Why might you use static cells in a UITableViewController storyboard scene?
options: To build simple form-like tables without data source code
To enable dynamic height for all cells
To remove the need for delegates

Medium.question: What does an unwind segue allow you to do?
options: Navigate back to a specific view controller in the stack

Medium.question: What is a risk of using storyboards heavily with Auto Layout?
options: Conflicting constraints can be harder to debug visually

Medium.question: What type of segue would you use to present a full-screen modal view?
options: Show (e.g. push) or Present Modally with full screen

Medium.question: Why is it often recommended to assign custom classes to view controllers in storyboards?
options: To connect the storyboard scene to the correct Swift class

Medium.question: Which setting in storyboard helps ensure UI adapts to different screen sizes?

Hard.question: What is a major merge conflict issue with storyboards in large teams?
options: They are XML files and can be difficult to merge manually
They cannot be committed to Git

Hard.question: Why might you prefer programmatic UI or SwiftUI over complex storyboard hierarchies?
options: Better control, reusability, and easier version control

Hard.question: How can you reduce storyboard bloat while still using Interface Builder?
options: Split UI into multiple storyboards or use XIBs for individual screens
Use only one storyboard for everything

Hard.question: What is a technical downside of using segues for all navigation logic?
options: Navigation logic becomes tightly coupled to storyboard structure
It always slows down the app

Hard.question: Why might you implement custom segue subclasses?
options: To customize transition animations or behavior

Hard.question: How can you instantiate a view controller from a storyboard without a segue?

options: Use prepare(for:sender:) and set properties on the destination
Use global variables for all data
Use notification center for all values

Hard.question: Why can overusing storyboard-based logic make refactoring harder?
options: Logic is spread across visual connections and code
Xcode does not open large storyboards

Hard.question: Which approach helps with dependency injection when using storyboards?
options: Instantiating controllers from storyboards in code and injecting dependencies manually
Always using segues with no configuration

Hard.question: When using storyboards, why might runtime crashes occur despite a clean compile?
options: Mismatched storyboard IDs, segue identifiers, or missing outlet connections
Too many images in the asset catalog

Easy.question: What is the main goal of async/await in Swift?
Which keyword is used to define an asynchronous function in Swift?
Which keyword is used before calling an asynchronous function?
Where can async functions be called directly without creating a Task?
What does concurrency mainly help with?
options: Keeping apps responsive during long tasks

Easy.question: Which construct is used to run asynchronous work in a synchronous context?
Which Swift feature replaced many closure-based completion handlers for async APIs?
What happens if you call an async function without await?
options: The function returns immediately without work

Easy.question: Which keyword is used to mark functions that can throw errors?
Which Swift construct lets you handle errors from async functions?

Medium.question: What is the type returned by an async function that does not explicitly return a value?
How can you run multiple async tasks in parallel and wait for all of them?
Which keyword combination defines a function that can both throw and be awaited?
In Swift concurrency, what does Task represent?
options: A UI element for to-do lists

Medium.question: Which Task initializer is used to create a detached task?
What is a potential issue of using detached tasks excessively?
options: They ignore structured concurrency, making cancellation and priority harder to manage
They disable async/await in other tasks

Medium.question: Which attribute allows an actor or class to bridge legacy closure-based APIs to async/await?
What does Task.sleep(nanoseconds:) do?
options: Suspends the current task for the given duration
Blocks the main thread for the given time

Medium.question: What feature of Swift concurrency helps avoid data races with shared mutable state?
Why is it important to mark long-running operations as async?
options: To avoid blocking threads and keep UI responsive

Hard.question: What is structured concurrency in Swift?
options: A model where tasks form a tree-like structure with clear parent-child relationships
A way to reorder async tasks randomly
A mechanism to manage only main thread work
A design pattern for class inheritance

Hard.question: Why might you use withCheckedContinuation?
options: To bridge a callback-based API into async/await safely

Hard.question: What does it mean that async functions are 'cooperative' with the scheduler?
options: They suspend at await points, allowing other tasks to run
They monopolize the thread until completion
They automatically run on the main thread
They always run on background threads

Hard.question: Why is calling blocking APIs inside async functions problematic?
options: It defeats concurrency by blocking threads instead of suspending

Hard.question: What is a key advantage of using actors over locks for concurrency control?
options: Actors provide isolation through language-level guarantees
Actors are always faster than locks

Hard.question: How does task cancellation propagate in structured concurrency?
options: Cancellation flows from parent tasks down to child tasks
Cancellation only applies to detached tasks

Hard.question: Why is it risky to capture self strongly in long-lived async tasks?
options: It can cause retain cycles and memory leaks
It stops other tasks from executing

Hard.question: What is a safe pattern to update UI from an async function?
options: Call UI code from any background Task

Hard.question: Why might you use TaskGroup?
options: To dynamically spawn and manage multiple child tasks and aggregate their results
To block threads in a group
To manage only main thread tasks

Hard.question: What is a common best practice when calling async functions inside SwiftUI views?
options: Trigger them from lifecycle events (like .task or .onAppear) instead of directly in body
Call them directly in the body without Task
Use detached tasks for all calls

When only fetching small JSON responses
